result.markdown:
--- title: "Scoring and Reliability Analysis of Psychometric Network" format: html editor: visual --- ## Minimal Example ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Loading required package: pacman ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exp1 <- matrix(c( 0, .8, .5, .8, 0, 0.1, .5, .1, 0 ), nrow = 3, ncol = 3, byrow = T) rownames(exp1) = colnames(exp1) = c("A", "B", "C") qgraph::qgraph(input = exp1, edge.labels=T, edge.label.cex = 1.7, edge.label.color = "black") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The centrality measures for three nodes: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mykbl(centrality(exp1)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
node Betweenness Closeness Strength ExpectedInfluence
A 1.155 1.114 1.044 1.044
B -0.577 -0.295 -0.095 -0.095
C -0.577 -0.819 -0.949 -0.949
````` ::: ::: Assume that there are two individuals with different scores on three items: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} response <- data.frame( A = c(1, 5), B = c(1, 1), C = c(5, 1) ) rownames(response) <- c("Person1", "Person2") mykbl(response) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
A B C
Person1 1 1 5
Person2 5 1 1
````` ::: ::: We can calculate the weighted network scores for them based on Strength centrality measures and their item scores ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} as.matrix(response) %*% centrality(exp1)[['Strength']] |> mykbl() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Person1 -3.797
Person2 4.176
````` ::: ::: The strength-based network score reflect one's **overall level of clusters of nodes in a network**.
